Translated by Tripiá¹­aka Master KumÄrajÄ«va of the Later Qin Dynasty, Respectfully Received by Imperial Decree Question:
What is meant by the perfection of giving?
Answer:
The meaning of giving has been explained above.
PÄramitÄ means to reach the other shore. This is called crossing the river of giving and reaching the other shore.
Question:
What is meant by not reaching the other shore?
Answer:
It is like crossing a river and turning back before reaching the other shore.
For example, ÅšÄriputra practiced the bodhisattva path for sixty eons and wanted to cross the river of giving.
At that time, a beggar came and asked for his eyes. ÅšÄriputra said:
The eyes are useless. Why do you ask for them?
If you need my body or wealth, I will give them to you!
The beggar replied:
I do not need your body or wealth, I only want your eyes.
If you truly practice giving, give me your eyes to see!
At that time, ÅšÄriputra took out an eye and gave it to him.
The beggar got the eye, sniffed it in front of ÅšÄriputra, spat on it in disgust, and threw it on the ground, then kicked it with his foot.
ÅšÄriputra thought to himself:
Such a vile person is difficult to save!
The eyes are truly useless, yet he forcefully demanded them. He got them and then discarded them, and even kicked them with his foot - how vile can one be!
Such people cannot be saved.
It is better to tame oneself and quickly escape birth and death.
Having thought this, he turned away from the path of the bodhisattva and turned towards the Lesser Vehicle. This is called not reaching the other shore.
If one can go straight ahead without turning back and accomplish the Buddha's path, it is called reaching the other shore.
Furthermore, accomplishing things is also called reaching the other shore. In the customs of India, whenever something is accomplished, it is said to reach the other shore.
Furthermore, this shore is called stinginess and greed, and giving is called the river. The other shore is called the Buddha's path.

Furthermore, views of existence and non-existence are called this shore, and the wisdom that destroys views of existence and non-existence is called the other shore. Diligent practice of giving is called the river.
Furthermore, there are two kinds of giving:
One is MÄra's giving, and the other is the Buddha's giving.
If one is robbed by the thieves of afflictions and experiences worry and fear, this is MÄra's giving, and it is called this shore.

If there is pure giving, without the thieves of afflictions and without fear, and one reaches the Buddha's path, this is the Buddha's giving, and it is called reaching the other shore. This is called pÄramitÄ.
As the Buddha said in the Sutra on the Parable of the Poisonous Snakes:
There was a man who offended the king. The king ordered him to guard a chest, in which there were four poisonous snakes.
The king ordered the criminal to watch over and raise the child.
This person thought:
The four snakes are difficult to approach, and if approached, they will harm people. One is already difficult to raise, let alone four!
He then abandoned the basket and ran away. The king ordered five people with drawn swords to chase after him.
There was also a person who spoke in a flattering manner, but in his heart wished to harm him, and said to him:
Raise it with reason, this is also not suffering!
The person realized this and ran away to save his life, to an empty village.
There was a good person who skillfully said to him:
Although this village is empty, it is where thieves stay. If you stay here, you will surely be harmed by thieves. Be careful not to stay!
Thus, he left again and reached a great river. The other side of the river was a different country.
That country was peaceful and happy, flat and pure, without any troubles or difficulties.
Then he gathered grass and wood, bound them into a raft, and with his hands and feet, he exerted himself to cross. Having reached the other shore, he was at ease and free from worries.
The king is the demon king;
The chest is the human body;
The four poisonous snakes are the four great elements;
The five robbers with drawn swords are the five aggregates;
The one whose mouth is good but whose heart is evil is attachment;
The empty village is the six sense faculties;
The robbers are the six sense objects;
The one who takes pity and speaks to him is the good teacher;
The great river is craving;
The raft is the eightfold noble path;
The diligent crossing with hands and feet is diligence;
This shore is the world;
The other shore is nirvana;
The one who crosses is an arhat who has exhausted the defilements.
In the Dharma of the bodhisattvas, giving also has three hindrances:
I give, he receives, and the wealth given - this falls into the realm of the demon king and is not free from difficulties.
Just as a bodhisattva's giving is pure in three ways, without these three hindrances, reaching the other shore, praised by the buddhas, this is called the perfection of giving.
Therefore it is called reaching the other shore.
These six perfections can enable people to cross the great ocean of afflictions such as stinginess and greed, and reach the other shore. Therefore they are called perfections.
Question:
Arhats and pratyekabuddhas are also able to reach the other shore. Why are they not called perfections?
Answer:
The arhats and pratyekabuddhas crossing to the other shore and the buddhas crossing to the other shore have the same name but different realities.
They take saá¹ƒsÄra as this shore and nirvÄá¹‡a as the other shore, but they are unable to cross to the other shore of giving.
Why is this?
They are unable to give everything, at all times, and in all ways;
even if they are able to give, they lack a great mind;
Or they give with a neutral mind, a mind with contaminated goodness, or a mind without outflows;
They do not have a mind of great compassion;
They are unable to give to all sentient beings.

The giving of bodhisattvas is to know that giving is unborn and unceasing, without outflows and unconditioned, like the characteristics of nirvana, and to give for the sake of all sentient beings. This is called the perfection of giving.
Furthermore, some people say:
All things, all kinds of internal and external things, are given without seeking any rewards;
Giving like this is called the perfection of giving.
Furthermore, it is called the perfection of giving because it is inexhaustible.
Why is this?
It is because one knows that the things given are ultimately empty, like the characteristics of nirvana;
One gives to sentient beings with this mind, and therefore the rewards of giving are inexhaustible, called the perfection of giving.
Like the five supernormal powers of the sages, they store precious treasures in rocks;
Wishing to protect this treasure, they polish it with diamonds and apply a coating to make it indestructible.
The bodhisattva's giving is also like this. Using the wisdom of the true characteristics of nirvana to polish and apply a coating to the giving, it becomes inexhaustible.
Furthermore, the bodhisattva gives for the sake of all sentient beings. Since the number of sentient beings is inexhaustible, giving is also inexhaustible.
Furthermore, the bodhisattva gives for the sake of the Buddha's teachings. Since the Buddha's teachings are immeasurable and boundless, giving is also immeasurable and boundless.
For this reason, although arhats and pratyekabuddhas reach the other shore, they are not called perfections.
Question:
What is meant by complete fulfillment?
Answer:

As explained above, bodhisattvas are able to give everything, internally and externally, large and small, much and little, coarse and fine, attached and unattached, used and unused, and so forth. They are able to give away all such things without any stinginess, equally sharing them with all sentient beings, without making distinctions such as:
I should give to the great, but not to the small;
I should give to those who have left the household life, but not to those who have not;
I should give to humans, but not to animals.
They give equally to all sentient beings with an impartial mind, and they give without seeking recompense. Moreover, they attain the true nature of giving. This is called being complete and full.

They do not consider time, with no day or night, no winter or summer, no good or bad luck. They always give equally at all times, with no regret or stinginess, even giving away their head, eyes, marrow, and brain without any reluctance. This is being complete and full.
Furthermore, some say:

From the initial arousal of the mind of enlightenment up to sitting under the bodhi tree and attaining the thirty-four mental states, during this period it is called the perfection of giving being fulfilled.

Furthermore, when the bodhisattva of the seventh stage attains the wisdom of the true characteristics of all dharmas, at that time he adorns the buddha lands, teaches and transforms sentient beings, makes offerings to the buddhas, attains great spiritual powers, and is able to divide his body into countless bodies, each body raining down the seven treasures, flowers, incense, banners, and canopies, and transforming into great lamps like Mount Sumeru, making offerings to the buddhas and bodhisattva saá¹…ghas of the ten directions;
he further praises the virtues of the buddhas with wonderful sounds, makes offerings by prostrating and bowing, and respectfully welcomes them.
Furthermore, this bodhisattva rains down various kinds of food, drink, and clothing in the innumerable ghost realms of the ten directions, causing them to be filled;
having been satisfied, they all arouse the mind of supreme, perfect enlightenment.
He then went to the animal realm, causing them to be kind to each other, without thoughts of harming one another, removing their fears, and satisfying their needs;
after they were satisfied, they all gave rise to the mind of supreme, perfect enlightenment.

In the immeasurable suffering of the hells, he was able to extinguish the fires, cool the boiling water, stop the offenses, and make their minds kind, removing their hunger and thirst, and causing them to be reborn in the heavens and among humans;
for this reason, they all gave rise to the mind of supreme, perfect enlightenment.
If he went to the poor in the ten directions, he would provide them with wealth, and to the wealthy and noble he would give them rare flavors and colors, causing them to rejoice;
for this reason, they all gave rise to the mind of supreme, perfect enlightenment.
If he went to the desire heavens, he would cause them to remove the pleasures of desire in the heavens and bestow upon them the wonderful Dharma treasures and pleasures, causing them to rejoice;
For this reason, they all give rise to the mind of supreme, perfect enlightenment.
If they reach the heavens of form, they eliminate attachment and entertain them with the dhyÄna methods of bodhisattvas;
For this reason, they all give rise to the mind of supreme, perfect enlightenment.
In this way, up to the tenth stage, this is called the perfection of generosity being fulfilled.
Next, there are two kinds of bodies for bodhisattvas:
First, the body born from karmic bonds; second, the Dharma body.
Among these two kinds of bodies, the perfection of generosity is fulfilled, which is called the perfection of generosity being complete.
Question:
What is meant by the perfection of generosity in the body born from karmic bonds?
Answer:

Without having attained the Dharma body and with afflictions not yet exhausted, one is able to give away all precious things, head, eyes, marrow, brain, country, wealth, wife, children, and all internal and external possessions, without wavering in mind.
Like Prince Sudinna (meaning well-loved in Chinese), who gave his two sons and wife to Brahmins without hesitation.
Also like King Sarvadatta (meaning all-giving in Chinese), who was overthrown by a rival country and fled to the deep forest.
He saw a Brahmin from a distant land who wanted to beg from him.

Thinking that his country had been destroyed, his family had perished, and he himself was in hiding, he felt pity for the Brahmin's hardship in coming from afar without any gain. He said to the Brahmin:
I am King Sarvadatta. The new king has offered a large reward for my capture.
He then bound himself and offered himself to the Brahmin, who sent him to the new king in exchange for a large sum of money.
It was also like Prince Candraprabha, who went out on a pleasure trip.
A leper saw him and asked for his carriage, saying:
I am suffering from a serious illness and am in great pain and distress. Prince, you are out enjoying yourself and having fun alone?
With your great compassion, please consider saving and treating me!
The prince heard this and asked the doctors.
The doctors said:
You must use the blood and marrow of a person who has been born and raised without anger, to smear and drink it, then it can be cured.
The prince thought:
Even if there is such a person, they would be greedy for life and cherish their life, how could they be obtained?
Except for my own body, there is no place to get it.
He then ordered the executioner to remove the flesh from his body, break the bones to extract the marrow to smear on the sick person, and drink the blood.
In this way, various things, his body, wife, and children, he gave without stinginess, like discarding grass and wood.

Contemplating the given objects, knowing they arise from conditions, investigating their reality, there is nothing to be obtained at all, all are pure, like the characteristics of nirvana, up to attaining the acceptance of the non-arising of dharmas, this is the perfection of the practice of giving the body born from karmic bonds.
What is the perfection of the practice of giving of a Dharma-body bodhisattva?
The bodhisattva, in his final flesh body, attained the forbearance of the non-arising of dharmas, and abandoned his flesh body to attain the dharma body.
In the ten directions and six realms, he transformed his body to adapt and liberate beings, providing all kinds of precious treasures, clothing, and food and drink.
He also gave away his head, eyes, marrow, brain, country, wealth, wife, children, and all internal and external possessions.
For example, ÅšÄkyamuni Buddha once was a six-tusked white elephant. A hunter waited for an opportunity and shot it with a poisoned arrow.
Other elephants rushed to trample the hunter to death.
The white elephant protected the man with its body, pitied him as if he were a child, and drove away the other elephants.
It slowly asked the hunter:
Why did you shoot me?
The hunter replied:
I need your tusks!
The elephant immediately inserted its six tusks into a crevice in the rock, with blood and flesh coming out together, and raised its trunk to pick up the tusks and give them to the hunter.
Although it is said to be an elephant's body, its mind is like this. You should know that this elephant is not an animal's karmic retribution.
In the Dharma of arhats, there is no such mind at all. You should know that this is a Dharma-body bodhisattva.
Sometimes the people of JambudvÄ«pa do not know how to pay respect.
The elders with virtue use words to transform them, but they are not yet able to be liberated.
At that time, the bodhisattva transformed his body and became a kalaviá¹…ka bird.
This bird had two close friends:
a great elephant and a monkey, who lived together under a pippala tree.
They asked each other:
We do not know who should be the elder.
The elephant said:
I once saw this tree under my belly, and now it is as big as this.
Judging from this, I should be the elder!
The monkey said:
I once squatted on the ground and pulled the top of the tree with my hands.
Judging from this, I should be the elder!
The bird said:
I ate the fruit of this tree in the Pibara forest, and the seeds came out in my excrement, giving rise to this tree.
Based on this, I should be the oldest!
The bird said again:
The one born first and oldest should be honored with offerings!
Then the great elephant carried the monkey on its back, and the bird perched on the monkey, wandering around.
All the birds and beasts saw this and asked:
Why is this so?
They replied:
This is to respectfully make offerings to the elder!
The birds and beasts accepted the transformation and all practiced paying respect, not encroaching on people's fields and not harming living beings.
The people were suspicious and wondered why all the birds and beasts were no longer causing harm.

A hunter entered the forest and saw the elephant carrying the monkey, the monkey wearing the bird on its head, walking respectfully and transforming the creatures, and the creatures all cultivating goodness.
He reported it to the people of the country, and the people each rejoiced, saying:
When the time comes for great peace, even birds and beasts will be benevolent!
People also imitated this and all practiced propriety and respect.
From ancient times to the present, the transformation has flowed through myriad generations.
One should know that this is a Dharma-body Bodhisattva.
Furthermore, a Dharma-body Bodhisattva, in a single instant, transforms into innumerable bodies to make offerings to the Buddhas of the ten directions;
In a single instant, he is able to transform immeasurable wealth and give it to sentient beings;
He is able to follow all superior, middling, and inferior sounds and, in a single instant, universally expound the Dharma for them;
Up to sitting under the Buddha tree.
Such various things are called the Dharma-body Bodhisattva's fulfillment of the perfection of giving.
Furthermore, there are three kinds of giving:
First, giving of material things; second, giving of offerings and respect; third, giving of the Dharma.
What is giving of material things?
Precious treasures, clothing, food, head, eyes, marrow, and brain - all such internal and external possessions are completely given as offerings, which is called material giving.
Respectful giving means with a pure mind of faith, respectfully bowing, sending off, welcoming, praising, circumambulating, and making offerings - such various acts are called respectful giving.

Giving of the Dharma means for the sake of virtue and morality, speaking, discussing, reciting, reading, lecturing, resolving doubts, and bestowing the five precepts - such various acts are given for the sake of the Buddha Way, which is called giving the Dharma.
When these three kinds of giving are fulfilled, it is called the fulfillment of the perfection of giving.
Furthermore, giving arises from the causes and conditions of three things:
First, a pure mind of faith; second, wealth and goods; third, the field of blessings.
The mind has three kinds:
If it is compassion, respect, or compassion and respect.
Giving to the poor, the lowly, and even animals is called compassionate giving.
Giving to the Buddha and Dharma-body Bodhisattvas is called respectful giving.
Giving to the old, the sick, the poor, Arhats, and Pratyekabuddhas is called respectful and compassionate giving.
The objects given are pure, not stolen or robbed, and given in a timely manner, not seeking fame or gain.
Sometimes great merit is obtained from the mind, sometimes great merit is obtained from the field of blessings, and sometimes great merit is obtained from wonderful objects.
The first is from the mind, such as the four immeasurable minds, the Buddha-remembrance samÄdhi, and giving one's body to a tiger. This is called obtaining great merit from the mind.
There are two kinds of fields of blessings:ğŸ”½1. Compassionate field of blessings, which can give rise to a compassionate mind;
2. Respectful field of blessings, which can give rise to a respectful mind.
Like King AÅ›oka, who offered earth to the Buddha.

Furthermore, among material offerings, like a woman who, drunk on wine and lost in thought, mistakenly offered a necklace of the seven treasures to the stÅ«pa of Buddha KÄÅ›yapa. Due to that merit and virtue, she was reborn in the Heaven of the Thirty-three.
There are various such [offerings], which are called material offerings.
Question:
DÄna means giving away wealth, so why is it said to be perfecting the Dharma of non-abandonment?
Answer:
There are two kinds of dÄna:
first, supramundane, and second, not supramundane.
Now, supramundane dÄna is explained as signless, and because it is signless, there is nothing to abandon. Therefore, it is said to be perfecting the Dharma of non-abandonment.
Furthermore, because material goods cannot be obtained, it is called nothing to abandon.
These goods are empty in the future and past, and in the present they are discriminated, without any fixed Dharma. For this reason, it is said to be nothing to abandon.
Furthermore, when the practitioner gives away wealth, he thinks that this giving has great merit, and relying on this, arrogance and the bonds of craving and so forth arise.
For this reason, it is said that there is nothing to give away.
Because there is nothing to give away, there is no arrogance, and because there is no arrogance, the bonds of craving and so forth do not arise.
Furthermore, there are two kinds of givers:
First, worldly people, and second, people who have transcended the world.
Worldly people can give away wealth but cannot give away giving;
People who have transcended the world can give away wealth and can give away giving.
Why is this?
Because wealth and the mind of giving are both unobtainable.
For this reason, it is said that they are fully endowed with the Dharma of nothing to give away.
Furthermore, in the perfection of giving, it is said:
The three things of wealth, giving, and recipient are unobtainable.
Question:
The combination of the three things is called giving;
Now, if the three things cannot be obtained, how can it be called the perfection of giving being fulfilled?
Now, if there is wealth, giving, and a recipient, how can the three things not be obtained?
The cloth that is given truly exists.
Why is it so?
Because there is the name of cloth, there is the dharma of cloth. If there were no dharma of cloth, there would also be no name of cloth;
Since there is the name, the cloth should truly exist.

Furthermore, cloth has length, has shortness, coarseness, fineness, whiteness, blackness, yellowness, redness, has causes, has conditions, has making, has breaking, has retribution, and gives rise to the mind according to the dharma.
Ten feet is long, five feet is short;
Thick thread is coarse, thin thread is fine;
According to the dye, there are colors;
Having thread is the cause, weaving tools are the conditions. Because of the combination of these causes and conditions, there is cloth.
Human effort is making, human destruction is breaking;
Protecting against cold and heat, covering the body, is called retribution.
When people obtain it, they are greatly delighted, and when they lose it, they are greatly worried.
Because of giving it away, one obtains blessings and aids the Way;
If one steals or robs it, one will be executed in the marketplace, and after death, one will enter hell.
For these various reasons, we know that this cloth exists. This is called the dharma of cloth. How can you say that the given object cannot be obtained?
Answer:
Your statement that it exists because it has a name is not correct.
How do we know this?
There are two kinds of names:
Some are real, and some are not real.
Unreal names are like a grass called thief in Chinese, which neither steals nor robs, but is called a thief in reality.
Also, like rabbit horns and turtle hair, they only have names but no reality.

Although cloth is not as nonexistent as rabbit horns and turtle hair, it exists because of the convergence of causes and conditions, and it does not exist because of the dispersion of causes and conditions.
Like a forest, like an army, these all have names but no reality.
It is like a wooden man, although there is a human name, one should not seek its human attributes.
Although there is a name in the cloth, one should also not seek the true reality of the cloth.
The cloth can give rise to the mind's thoughts, obtaining it one is delighted, losing it one is worried, this is the cause and condition of thoughts.
The arising of the mind has two causes and conditions:
Some arise from the real, some arise from the unreal.
Like what is seen in a dream, like the moon in the water, like seeing a stump at night and taking it to be a person, this is called arising from the unreal.
This condition is uncertain, one should not say that because the mind arises there is existence.
If there is existence because of the causes and conditions of the arising of the mind, one should not seek true existence again.
It is like the eye seeing the moon in the water, the mind arises and takes it to be the moon, if what arises from the mind is the moon, then there is no true moon.
Furthermore, existence has three kinds:
First, relative existence, second, nominal existence, and third, real existence.
Relative means like long and short, this and that, etc. In reality there is no long or short, nor is there this or that. Because of mutual dependence, they have names.
Longness is due to shortness, and shortness is also due to longness;
This is due to that, and that is also due to this;
If it is to the east of an object, it is considered west, and if it is to the west, it is considered east;
A single object is not different, yet there is a distinction between east and west. These all have names but no reality.
Such things are called relative existence. There is no real dharma here, unlike form, smell, taste, touch, etc.
Nominal existence means that curd has color, smell, taste, and touch. The combination of these four causes and conditions is provisionally called curd.
Although it exists, it is not the same as the existence of causal dharmas;
Although it does not exist, it is also not the non-existence of a rabbit's horns or a turtle's hair;
But because of the combination of causes and conditions, it is provisionally called curds.
Cloth is also like this.

Furthermore, because there are extremely subtle colors, smells, tastes, and textures, there are hair parts. Because of the causes and conditions of hair parts, there is hair. Because of the causes and conditions of hair, there is down. Because of the causes and conditions of down, there are threads. Because of the causes and conditions of threads, there is cloth. Because of the causes and conditions of cloth, there are garments.

If there are no causes and conditions of extremely subtle colors, smells, tastes, and textures, there are also no hair parts. Because hair parts do not exist, there is also no hair. Because hair does not exist, there is also no down. Because down does not exist, there are also no threads. Because threads do not exist, there is also no cloth. Because cloth does not exist, there are also no garments.
Question:

It is not necessarily the case that all things exist because of the combination of causes and conditions. For example, atoms are extremely subtle, so they have no parts. Because they have no parts, they do not combine.
Cloth is coarse, so it can be broken. But atoms have no parts, so how can they be broken?
Answer:
Extremely subtle [atoms] are unreal, yet we forcefully give them a name.
Why is this?
Coarse and subtle are mutually dependent. Because of the coarse, there is the subtle. This subtlety should also have subtlety.
Moreover, if there is an atom of form, then there are parts in the ten directions;
if there are parts in the ten directions, it cannot be called an atom;
if there are no parts in the ten directions, it cannot be called form.
Moreover, if there is an atom, then there should be a boundary in space;
if there are parts, then it cannot be called an atom.
Moreover, if there is an atom, then within it there are parts of form, smell, taste, and touch. Parts of form, smell, taste, and touch are not called atoms.
Thus, when seeking through reasoning, the atom cannot be found.
As the sutra says:
Form, whether coarse or subtle, whether internal or external, when viewed in total, is impermanent and without self.
It does not say there are atoms.
This is called the emptiness of division.
There is also the contemplation of emptiness:
This cloth is as one wishes.
Like a meditator contemplating the cloth as either earth, water, fire, or wind, or as blue, yellow, white, or red, or as completely empty, like the ten universal contemplations.
As the Buddha was on Gá¹›dhrakÅ«á¹­a Mountain, together with the assembly of bhiká¹£us, entering the city of RÄjagá¹›ha.
On the road, he saw a large body of water. The Buddha spread out his niá¹£Ä«dana on the water and sat down, telling the bhiká¹£us:
If a bhiká¹£u enters meditation and gains mastery of the mind, he can transform the large body of water into earth, which then becomes solid ground.
Why is this?
Because within that water there is a component of earth.
In the same way, water, fire, wind, gold, silver, and various precious substances can all be transformed into solid objects.
Why is this?
Because within that water there are all their components.
Furthermore, like a single beautiful person, a lustful person sees them as pure and wonderful, giving rise to defiled attachment;
When a person who contemplates impurity sees it, they see various kinds of filth and no pure place.
When a jealous wife sees it, she is jealous, hateful, and detests it, not wanting to look at it, considering it impure.
A lustful person sees it as pleasure.
A jealous person sees it as suffering.
A practitioner sees it and attains the Way.
A neutral person sees it and has no preference, like seeing earth and wood.
If this beautiful form were truly pure, the four kinds of people would all see it as pure.
If it were truly impure, the four kinds of people would all see it as impure.
Therefore, we know that beauty and ugliness are in the mind, and there is no fixed [reality] outside.
Contemplating emptiness is also like this.
Furthermore, because this cloth has the characteristics of the eighteen kinds of emptiness, when contemplated, it is empty. Because it is empty, it cannot be obtained.
In this way, various causes and conditions show that wealth is empty and definitely cannot be obtained.
How can the person who receives the gift not be obtainable?
Just as a cloth exists due to the combination of causes and conditions, when analyzed part by part, the cloth cannot be found.
Giving is also like this. The four elements surround emptiness and are called the body. The consciousness of this body moves back and forth, sitting and rising, and is provisionally called a person.
When sought part by part, it also cannot be found.
Furthermore, within all the aggregates, realms, and sense bases, the self cannot be found. Since the self cannot be found, the giver cannot be found.
Why is this?
The self has various names:
humans, gods, men, women, givers, receivers, those who experience suffering, those who experience happiness, animals, and so forth;
these are merely names, but the real dharma cannot be found.
Question:
If the giver cannot be found, how can there be a bodhisattva practicing the perfection of giving?
Answer:
Names exist due to the combination of causes and conditions, like a house, like a cart, but the real dharma cannot be found.
Question:
How is the self unobtainable?
Answer:
As explained above in I have heard, at one time, it will now be further explained.
The Buddha speaks of the six consciousnesses:
Eye consciousness and dharmas associated with eye consciousness, together perceiving form, not perceiving houses, cities, and various names.
Ear, nose, tongue, and body consciousness are also like this.
Mental consciousness and dharmas associated with mental consciousness know the eye, know form, know eye consciousness, up to knowing the mind, knowing dharmas, and knowing mental consciousness.
The dharmas that are the objects of these consciousnesses are all empty and without self, because they arise and cease, and because they are not independent.
Even in unconditioned dharmas, one does not conceive of a self, because one does not experience suffering or pleasure.
If there were a self-nature here, there should be a seventh consciousness that cognizes the self;
But now it is not so, therefore one knows there is no self.
Question:
Why is it known that there is no self?
All people each give rise to the notion of self within their own bodies, not within others' bodies.
If there is no self within one's own body, and one falsely sees it as self, then since there is also no self within others' bodies, one should also falsely see it as self within others' bodies.
Moreover, if there is no self internally, and form and consciousness arise and cease moment by moment, how does one discriminate and know that this form is blue, yellow, red, or white?

Moreover, if there is no self, and the consciousness of a person in the present gradually arises and ceases, and when the body and life end it also ends, then who follows and experiences the actions and merits and demerits?
Who experiences suffering and pleasure?
Who is the one who is liberated?
For these and other various reasons, one knows that there is a self.
Answer:
Both of these have difficulties!
If one gives rise to the notion of self within others' bodies, one should also say, Why not give rise to the notion of self within one's own body?

Furthermore, the five aggregates are empty and without self because they arise from conditions. From the condition of ignorance, the twenty views of the body arise. This view of self arises from the continuity of the five aggregates.
Because they arise from the conditions of these five aggregates, one then takes these five aggregates to be the self, not in another's body, due to habit.
Furthermore, if there were a spirit, then there could be that self.
You have not yet understood whether the spirit exists or not, yet you ask about that self!
It is like a person asking about the horns of a rabbit, and the answer is similar to the horns of a horse.
If the horns of a horse truly exist, then they can be used to prove the horns of a rabbit;
but the horns of a horse are still not understood, yet you want to use them to prove the horns of a rabbit.
Furthermore, because the view of self arises in one's own body, one then considers oneself to have a spirit.
You say that the spirit is omnipresent, and you should also consider another's body to be the self.
For this reason, one should not say that the mind that grasps at the view of self arises in one's own body but not in another's body, and therefore know that there is a spirit.

Furthermore, some people give rise to the thought of self towards other people's possessions, like the non-Buddhist practitioners of meditation. When they practice the meditation of earth-pervasiveness, they see earth as self and self as earth, and the same is so for water, fire, wind, and space.
Because of delusion, they also conceive of self in other people's bodies.
Furthermore, sometimes they give rise to the thought of self towards other people's bodies. For example, there was once a person who was sent on a long journey and stayed alone in an empty house.
In the night, a ghost carried a dead person and placed it in front of him, and another ghost chased after him, angrily scolding the first ghost:
This dead person is my possession. Why did you carry it here?
The first ghost said:
It is my possession. I brought it myself.
The second ghost said:
I really carried this dead person here!
The two ghosts each grabbed one hand and argued.
The first ghost said:
We can ask this person here.
The second ghost then asked:
Who carried this dead person here?
This person thought:
The power of these two ghosts is great. If I speak the truth, I will die. If I speak falsely, I will also die. Both cannot avoid death. Why speak falsely?
He said:
The previous ghost carried him here.
The later ghost became very angry, grabbed the person's hand, pulled it out and put it on the ground. The previous ghost took an arm from the dead person and put it on.
In this way, both arms, both legs, the head, and the sides, the entire body was exchanged.
Then the two ghosts together ate the person's body that was exchanged, wiped their mouths, and left.
That person thought:
The body my mother gave birth to, I saw with my own eyes the two ghosts eat it all. Now this body of mine is all his flesh.
Do I definitely have a body now?
Or do I not have a body?
If I think I have, it is all his body;
If I think I do not have, I now have a body.
Thinking like this, his mind became confused, like a madman.
The next morning, he continued on his way and arrived at a country where he saw a Buddhist temple and monks. Without discussing other matters, he only asked about his own existence.
The monks asked:
Who are you?
He replied:
I myself do not know if I am a person or not a person?
He then explained the above events in detail to the monks.
The monks said:
This person knows himself to be without self, and is easy to save.
They told him:
Your body has always been without self from the beginning, not just now.
It is only because the four elements are combined that it is considered your body. It is no different from your original body.
The monks ordained him and he eliminated all afflictions, and immediately attained arhatship.
This is an example of sometimes taking another's body as one's own.
It cannot be said that there is a self because there is this and that.
Furthermore, the true nature of the self is definitely unobtainable.

Whether it has the characteristics of permanence or impermanence, being self-controlled or not self-controlled, being an agent or not being an agent, having form or not having form, all such kinds are unobtainable.
If there are characteristics, then there are dharmas; if there are no characteristics, then there are no dharmas. Since I now have no characteristics, I know there is no self.
If the self is permanent, there should be no sin of killing.
Why is it so?
Because the body can be killed, it is impermanent;
The self cannot be killed, because it is permanent.
Question:
Although the self cannot be killed because it is permanent, killing the body still results in the sin of killing.
Answer:
If killing the body results in the sin of killing, then the Vinaya says:
Killing oneself does not result in the sin of killing.
Sin and merit arise from harming or benefiting others, not from self-worship or self-harm, so there is sin and merit.
Therefore, in the Vinaya it is said:
Self-harm is not a crime of killing, but there is the fault of delusion, desire, and anger.
If the spirit is eternal, it should not die and should not be born.
Why is it so?
According to your teachings, the spirit is eternal and pervades the five realms. How can there be death and birth?
Death is losing this place, and birth is appearing in that place.
Therefore, one cannot say that the spirit is eternal.
If the spirit is eternal, it should also not experience suffering and pleasure.
Why is it so?
When suffering comes, one worries, and when pleasure arrives, one is happy. If one is changed by worry and joy, then it is not eternal.
If it is eternal, it should be like empty space, not wet by rain, not dried by heat, and not exist in this world or the next.
If the spirit is permanent, there should be no rebirth in the next world or death in this world.
If the spirit is permanent, it would always have the view of self and should not attain nirvana.
If the spirit is permanent, it would be without arising and without cessation, and should not have forgetfulness;
because it is without spirit and consciousness is impermanent, there is forgetfulness and loss, therefore the spirit is not permanent.
In this way, through various reasons, one can know that the spirit is not of the characteristic of permanence.
If the spirit is of the characteristic of impermanence, then there would be no sin and no merit.
If the body is impermanent and the spirit is also impermanent, the two things would both cease, then one would fall into the extreme of annihilation.
Falling into annihilation, there would be no one who goes to the next world to experience sin and merit.
If there is annihilation, one would attain nirvana without needing to sever the bonds, and would not need the causes and conditions of sin and merit in the next world.
In this way, through various reasons, one can know that the spirit is not impermanent.
If the self were sovereign and creative, then one would be able to obtain whatever one desires.
But now one does not obtain what one desires and instead obtains what one does not desire.
If the self were sovereign, one would not commit evil deeds and fall into the evil destinies of animals.
Moreover, all sentient beings do not enjoy suffering. Who would delight in suffering and obtain suffering again?
Therefore, we know that the self is not sovereign and does not create.
Moreover, because people fear offenses, they forcibly practice goodness. If the self were sovereign, why would one fear offenses and forcibly cultivate blessings?
Moreover, sentient beings are unable to do as they wish and are always dragged along by afflictions and the bonds of craving.
For these various reasons, we know that the self is not sovereign and does not create itself.
If the self is not sovereign and does not create itself, this is the characteristic of non-self. The so-called self is simply the six consciousnesses, nothing else.
Furthermore, if one does not do it oneself, how would King Yama ask the sinner:
Who made you commit this crime?
The sinner would answer:
It was I myself who did it.
Therefore, we know that it is not not done by oneself.
If one says it is the characteristics of form and mind, this is not so.
Why is it so?
Because all forms are impermanent.
Question:
How can people say form is my characteristic?
Answer:
Some people say:
The spirit is in the heart, subtle like a mustard seed, pure and called the pure form body.
Some say it is like wheat, some say it is like beans, some say it is half an inch, some say it is one inch.
When first receiving a body, it is received first, like the skeleton of an image;
When the body is complete, it is like the image already adorned.
Some say:
The size of the body follows the human body, and when it dies and decays, it also comes out first.
But this is not so!
Why is it so?
All forms are created by the four great elements and arise from causes and conditions, so they are impermanent.
If the spirit is form, and form is impermanent, the spirit is also impermanent.
If it is impermanent, as explained above...
Question:
The body is of two kinds:
The coarse body and the subtle body.
The coarse body is impermanent, while the subtle body is the spirit, which goes from generation to generation and enters the five realms.
Answer:
This subtle body cannot be obtained.
If there is a subtle body, there should be a place where it can be obtained. If we search in each of the five internal organs and the four limbs, it cannot be found.
Question:
This subtle body is very subtle. It leaves when one first dies. If it is alive, it cannot be sought or obtained. How can you see it?
Moreover, this subtle body cannot be seen or known by the five sense faculties, only the sages with spiritual powers can see it.
Answer:
If so, it is no different from non-existence.
When a person dies, they abandon this birth existence and enter the intermediate existence.
At that time, the body of this world perishes, and they receive the body of the intermediate existence. There is no sequence here, as it perishes and is born simultaneously.
It is like a wax seal stamping mud; the seal is immediately destroyed as the mud receives the seal. Formation and destruction occur simultaneously, without sequence.
At that time, they receive the intermediate existence in the intermediate existence, and abandon this intermediate existence to receive the birth existence.
What you call the subtle body is precisely this intermediate existence. The body of the intermediate existence has no exit or entry.
It is like a burning lamp, with the continuity of arising and ceasing, neither permanent nor interrupted.
The Buddha said:
All forms, whether past, future, or present, internal or external, coarse or subtle, are all impermanent.
The spirit's subtle form should also be impermanent and subject to annihilation.
For these various reasons, we know it is not of the nature of form.
The spirit is not of the nature of formlessness. Formless means the four assemblies and the unconditioned.
The four assemblies are impermanent, not self-controlled, and dependent on conditions, so they cannot be the spirit.
Among the three unconditioned things, we do not consider them to be the spirit, because they do not experience anything.
For these various reasons, we know the spirit is not of the nature of formlessness.
Thus, between heaven and earth, internally and externally, in the three times and ten directions, we cannot find a self.

But the combination of the twelve sense bases gives rise to the six consciousnesses, and the combination of the three things is called contact. Contact gives rise to the mental factors of feeling, perception, and volition, etc.
In these dharmas, due to the power of ignorance, the view of a self arises, and because the view of a self arises, we think there is a spirit.

This view of self is eliminated when one sees the truth of suffering, and when the knowledge of the truth of suffering and inferential knowledge are attained. At that time, one does not see the existence of a soul.
You said before:
If there is no soul within, and the consciousness of form arises and ceases moment by moment, how can one distinguish and know that form is blue, yellow, red, or white?
Even if you have a soul, it cannot know by itself. It must rely on eye consciousness to know.
If that is so, then the soul is useless.
When eye consciousness knows form, form arises and ceases, similar forms arise and similar forms cease, and then a mental factor arises in the mind, called memory.
The characteristic of this memory is a conditioned dharma. Although it ceases and passes away, this memory can know.
Just as a sage's power of wisdom can know events in the future,
memory is also like this, able to know past dharmas.
If the previous eye consciousness ceases and gives rise to subsequent eye consciousness, the subsequent eye consciousness becomes sharper and more powerful.
Although form exists temporarily and does not abide, one can know it through the power of mindfulness.
For this reason, although it arises and ceases moment by moment and is impermanent, one can distinguish and know form.
Moreover, you say:
Now, the consciousness of a present person is newly arising and ceasing. When the body and life end, they also end. Among the various practices, merits and virtues, who follows and who receives?
Who experiences suffering and pleasure?
Who is liberated?
Now I will answer you:

Now, those who have not yet attained the true path have their minds covered by various afflictions, creating the causes and conditions for rebirth. At the time of death, the five aggregates continue to give rise to the five aggregates.
It is like one lamp further lighting another lamp.
Moreover, the arising of grains has three causes and conditions:
soil, water, and seeds.
The arising of the body in the next life is also like this.
There is a body, there is defiled karma, and there are afflictions. For these three reasons, the subsequent body arises.
In this case, the body and karmic causes and conditions cannot be cut off or destroyed, but the afflictions can be cut off.
When the afflictions are cut off, even if there is a remaining body and remaining karma, one can still attain liberation.
It is like having seeds and soil, but without water, they do not grow.
In the same way, even if there is a body and karma, without the nourishing water of craving, they do not grow.
This is called being without a self, and also attaining liberation.
Because of ignorance one is bound, and because of wisdom one is liberated, so there is no need for a self.
Furthermore, the combination of name and form is provisionally called a person.
This person, bound by afflictions, attains the nail of uncontaminated wisdom and unties these afflictions. At this time, it is said that the person attains liberation.
It is like a rope knot, a rope untied. The rope is the knot, and the knot is not a separate dharma. In the world, it is said to tie a rope and untie a rope.
Name and form are also like this. The combination of the two dharmas of name and form is provisionally called a person.
These afflictions are not different from name-and-form, they are simply called the bonds of name-and-form and the liberation of name-and-form.

Receiving blessings and offenses is also like this. Although there is no single dharma that truly constitutes a person, because of name-and-form one receives the fruits of blessings and offenses, and thus a person is given a name.
It is like a cart carrying goods. If one examines each individual thing, there is ultimately no real cart, yet the cart is given the name of that which carries the goods.
A person receiving blessings and offenses is also like this. Name-and-form receives blessings and offenses, while the person is given the name of that which receives them.
Receiving suffering and joy is also like this.
There are various reasons why the spirit cannot be found.
The spirit is the one who gives, and the receiver is also like this.
You take the spirit to be the person, and therefore the person who gives cannot be found, and the person who receives is also like this.
There are various reasons why the person who gives and the person who receives cannot be found.
Question:
If one gives to all dharmas, which are of suchness, with no destruction, no cessation, no arising, and no creation, why is it said that the three things cannot be obtained through analysis?
The answer is:

Ordinary people see the giver, see the recipient, and see the wealth, which is a deluded and inverted view. They give rise to worldly happiness, but when their blessings are exhausted, they turn back.
Therefore, the Buddha wants bodhisattvas to practice the true path and attain the true fruition. The true fruition is precisely the Buddha's path.
The Buddha speaks of the unobtainability of the three things in order to destroy false views, but there is actually nothing to destroy.
Why is this?
Because all dharmas have been empty from the very beginning.
For such various immeasurable reasons, they cannot be obtained, and this is called the perfection of the perfection of giving.
Furthermore, if a bodhisattva practices the perfection of giving and is able to give rise to the six perfections, at that time it is called the perfection of giving being fully perfected.
How does giving rise to the perfection of giving?ğŸ”½There are three levels of giving:
From the lower level one gives rise to the middle level, and from the middle level one gives rise to the upper level.
If one gives with a soft heart using coarse things such as food and drink, this is called the lower level;
As one's practice of giving increases, one is able to give clothing and precious things as gifts, this is giving rise to the middle level from the lower level;

As one's mind of giving increases, nothing is cherished, and one is able to give one's head, eyes, blood, flesh, country, wealth, wife, and children as gifts, this is giving rise to the upper level from the middle level.

Just as when ÅšÄkyamuni Buddha first gave rise to the aspiration for enlightenment, he was a great king named Guangming, seeking the path of buddhahood, giving a little bit as a gift.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
In his next life, he became a potter and offered bathing supplies and rock candy drinks to the Buddha ÅšÄkyamuni and the assembly of bhiká¹£us.
In his next life, he was reborn as the daughter of a great elder and offered lamps to Buddha KÄÅ›yapa.
Such various acts are called the bodhisattva's lower giving.
For example, when ÅšÄkyamuni Buddha was originally a young man, he offered his robe to Buddha MahÄghosa;
after the Buddha's parinirvÄá¹‡a, he built ninety stupas.ğŸ”½Later, he was reborn as a great king and offered a jeweled canopy to Buddha Siá¹ƒha.
Later, he was reborn as a great elder and offered excellent dwellings and jeweled flowers to Buddha Sunetra.
Such various acts are called the bodhisattva's middling giving.

For example, when ÅšÄkyamuni Buddha was originally a sage, he saw KÄÅ›yapa Buddha's dignified and wondrous appearance, and then jumped from a high mountain in front of the Buddha, his body safe and sound, standing to one side.
Also, like the Bodhisattva SarvasattvapriyadarÅ›ana, who used his body as a lamp to make offerings to the Buddha SÅ«ryapradÄ«pa.
In this way, he spared no life in making offerings to the buddhas. This is the highest giving of bodhisattvas.
This is called the bodhisattva's three kinds of giving.
If there are those who first give rise to the Buddha-mind and give to sentient beings, it is also like this.
First, they give food and drink, and as the mind of giving increases, they are able to give their own flesh and blood.
First, they give various fine beverages, and later as the mind further increases, they are able to give their own blood.
First, they give paper, ink, and scriptures, as well as clothing, food, and drink, making offerings in four ways to the Dharma teachers;
Later, attaining the Dharma body, for innumerable sentient beings he expounds various teachings, thus practicing the giving of Dharma.
In this way, various [forms of giving] arise from the perfection of giving, and from them the perfection of giving arises.
How does giving give rise to the perfection of morality for bodhisattvas?
Bodhisattvas contemplate:
Because sentient beings do not give, they are poor in future lives;
because of poverty, the thought of robbery arises;
because of robbery, there is killing;
because of poverty, they are insufficient in form;
because of insufficiency in form, they engage in sexual misconduct.
Moreover, because of poverty, they become lowly in the eyes of others;
out of fear of lowliness, they tell lies - in this way, due to the causes and conditions of poverty, they engage in the ten unwholesome courses of action.
If one practices giving, one will be reborn with wealth and resources. Because of having wealth and resources, one does not engage in unwholesome activities.
Why is this?
Because the five sense objects are abundant and there is nothing lacking.
In the past, Devadatta was once a snake, a frog, and a turtle, living in a pond, and they became close friends.
Later, when the pond dried up, they became hungry and destitute, with nowhere to turn.
At that time, the snake sent the turtle to call the frog, and the frog spoke a verse to send the turtle away, saying:
If one encounters poverty and loses one's original mind, one will not think of the original meaning, but food comes first.
You take my voice and tell it to the snake, but the frog will never come to you.

If one cultivates giving, one will be born with blessings in the next life, without any lack, and will then be able to keep the precepts, without these various evils. This is how giving can give rise to the perfection of morality.
Furthermore, when practicing giving, one can weaken the afflictions of breaking the precepts, benefit the mind of keeping the precepts, and make it firm.
This is how the causes and conditions of giving increase the precepts.

Furthermore, when a bodhisattva practices giving, he always gives rise to a compassionate mind towards the recipient, is not attached to wealth, and does not begrudge his own possessions, let alone stealing from others.
How could one who has compassion for the recipient have the intention to kill?
Such things can prevent one from breaking the precepts, and this is how giving gives rise to morality.
If one is able to give in order to break through the mind of stinginess, then it will be easy to practice morality, patience, and so forth.
As for MaÃ±juÅ›rÄ«, in the distant past, many kalpas ago, he was once a bhiká¹£u who entered the city to beg for alms and obtained a full bowl of delicious sesame cakes.
A small child in the city chased after him and begged for some.
He did not give it to him immediately, and when they reached the Buddha's stÅ«pa, he took two cakes and made a promise, saying:
If you can eat one cake yourself and offer one cake to the Sangha, I will give it to you!
They agreed and gave a single ball of joy to the assembly of monks, and then received the precepts from MaÃ±juÅ›rÄ« and generated the intention to become a Buddha.
Such giving can cause one to receive the precepts and generate the intention to become a Buddha. This is how giving arises as the perfection of morality.
Furthermore, the reward for giving is to obtain the four kinds of offerings, a good country, a good teacher, and to lack nothing, and thus one is able to uphold the precepts.
Moreover, the reward for giving is that one's mind becomes pliable;ğŸ”½because the mind is pliable, one is able to give rise to upholding the precepts;
because one is able to give rise to upholding the precepts, one is able to restrain one's mind from unwholesome dharmas.
In this way, there are various causes and conditions by which giving arises as the perfection of morality.
How does giving arise as the perfection of patience?
When a bodhisattva is giving, the recipient may insult him, demand a lot, ask at the wrong time, or ask for something that should not be asked for.
At that time, the bodhisattva thinks to himself:
I now give alms, wishing to seek Buddhahood, and there is no one who makes me give alms.
I do it for myself, so why give rise to anger?
Thinking like this, he practices patience, which is called giving birth to the perfection of forbearance through giving.
Furthermore, when the bodhisattva gives alms, if the recipient becomes angry and distressed, he then thinks to himself:
I now give away internal and external wealth, which is difficult to part with but I can do it, so how can I not endure empty words?
If I cannot endure them, then the alms I give will be impure.
It is like a white elephant that enters the pond to bathe, and after coming out, it uses soil to cover its body;
Giving alms without forbearance is also like this.
Thinking like this, he practices patience.
In these various ways, giving birth to the perfection of forbearance through giving.
How does giving birth to the perfection of vigor through giving?
When bodhisattvas practice giving, they always engage in diligence.
Why is this?

When bodhisattvas first generate the aspiration for enlightenment, their merit is not yet great. At that time, they wish to practice the two kinds of giving to fulfill the wishes of all sentient beings.
Because the objects are insufficient, they diligently seek wealth and the Dharma to provide for them.
Like ÅšÄkyamuni Buddha in a past life, he became a great physician who cured all illnesses, not seeking fame or profit, but out of compassion for sentient beings.

The number of sick people was so great that he could not save them all with his limited abilities. He worried about everyone but could not fulfill their wishes, and died in distress, then was reborn in the Heaven of the Thirty-three.
He thought to himself:
I have now been born in the heavens, but I only enjoy the rewards of my blessings without any benefit to others.
He then took expedient means to end his own life and gave up his heavenly lifespan.
He was reborn in the palace of the nÄga king VÄsuki as the nÄga prince.

The dragon's body was huge, and his parents loved him dearly. They wanted to die together and went to the king of the garuá¸as. The garuá¸a then took the dragon child and swallowed him on the Å›amÄ« tree.
The parents wailed and cried in distress.
After the dragon child died, he was reborn in JambudvÄ«pa as the prince of a great king, named DÄnapati.
As soon as he was born, he could speak and asked those around him:
What things are there in this country now? Bring them all and use them for giving!
The people were astonished and frightened, and all fled.
His mother pitied and loved him, and stayed alone to watch over him.
He said to his mother:
I am not a rÄká¹£asa. Why are the people running away?
I have always loved giving in my past lives. I am a dÄnapati for all people.
When his mother heard his words, she told the people, and the people then returned.
His mother raised him well, and when he grew up, he gave away all his possessions.
He went to his father's place and asked for things to give in charity. His father gave him his share, but he gave it all away again.
Seeing that the people of JambudvÄ«pa were poor and suffering, he wanted to provide for them but did not have enough wealth. He then wept for himself and asked the people,
What expedient means can I use to make everyone satisfied with wealth?
The elders said,
We have heard that there is a wish-fulfilling jewel on the head of the dragon king. If one obtains this jewel, then one can obtain whatever one wishes for according to one's mind.
When the Bodhisattva heard these words, he said to his parents,
I want to enter the great ocean to seek the wish-fulfilling jewel on the head of the dragon king.
His parents replied,
We only have you as our one child. If you enter the great ocean, the many difficulties are hard to cross.
If we lose you in one day, what use would it be for us to live?
You should not go!
We still have some wealth in our storehouse. We will give it to you!
The son said:
The treasure is limited, but my mind is boundless.
I wish to fill everything with wealth, to make everyone without lack or shortage. I hope you will allow me to fulfill my original intention and make everyone in JambudvÄ«pa completely satisfied!
His parents knew his ambition was great and did not dare to restrain him, so they let him go.
At that time, five hundred merchants, because of his great merit and virtue, all enjoyed following him;
knowing the day of his departure, they gathered at the mouth of the ocean route.
The Bodhisattva had previously heard that on the head of the dragon king BhagavÄn there was a wish-fulfilling jewel. He asked the people:
Who knows the sea route to the dragon palace?
There was a blind man named DÄsaka who had entered the great ocean seven times and was well acquainted with the sea route.
The Bodhisattva immediately ordered him to go together.
He replied:
I am already old and both my eyes are blind. Although I have entered many times before, I cannot go now!
The Bodhisattva said:

My present practice is not for myself alone. I seek the wish-fulfilling jewel for the sake of all, wishing to provide for sentient beings and make their bodies free from want, and then to teach and transform them through the principles of the Way.
You are a wise person, how can you refuse?
If my vow is fulfilled, is it not due to your power?
DhÄÅ›aka heard his earnest words, joyfully shared his thoughts, and said to the Bodhisattva:
I will now enter the great ocean with you. I will certainly not survive. You must place my corpse on the Golden Sand Island in the middle of the great ocean.
The preparations were all made, and the seventh rope was cut. The ship sped on and reached the island of treasures.
The merchants competed to take the seven treasures, each having taken enough.
They said to the Bodhisattva:
Why don't you take any?
The Bodhisattva replied:
What I seek is a wish-fulfilling jewel. This is a perishable thing, so I do not need it.
You should each know contentment and moderation, so that the ship does not become too heavy and we cannot escape.
At that time, the merchants said to the Bodhisattva:
Virtuous One!
Please bless us so that we may be safe!
Then they took their leave and departed.
At that time, Dasha said to the Bodhisattva:
Keep a separate boat and go by a different route.
Wait for the wind for seven days. Sail south of the ocean and reach a dangerous place with a cliff. The branches of the jujube trees are all covered with water.
The strong wind will blow the boat and it will capsize!
You should lean on the jujube branches to save yourself.
I am blind and will die here.
Past this dangerous shore, there will be a golden sand island. You can place my body on the sand;
the golden sand is pure, and this is my wish!
He then did as he was told, and the wind arrived and carried him away.
When he reached the sheer cliff, it was as DÄ«rghanakha had said.
The Bodhisattva grabbed a branch of a jujube tree and was able to save himself.
He placed DÄ«rghanakha's corpse and buried it in a golden place, and then left alone.

As instructed, he floated in the deep water for seven days, walked in the water up to his neck for seven days, walked in the water up to his waist for seven days, walked in the water up to his knees for seven days, and walked in the mud for seven days.
